EXECUTIVE SUMMARY - HOUSTON GAS PLANT

MarkWest Energy Partners L.P., owner and operator of the Houston Gas Plant, has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes.  Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.  However, if a release does occur, facility trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release.


DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The Houston Gas Plant processes raw gas from a field gathering system.  Produced natural gas is brought into the plant where it is first dehydrated to remove water.  The gas is then sent through refrigeration dew point control units where the condensable liquids will be extracted from the methane gas stream.  The gas is then sent through the turbo expander for additional pressure drop and liquids removal.  After passing through the turbo expander both the gas and liquids are sent to the deethanizer tower through different inlet trays.  The gas rises through the top and is ready to be sent into the sales pipeline.  The liquids are separated and sent through the bottom and to the surge tank and depropanzier.  A fractionator process then takes the B-G liquids and separates the iso- and normal- butane leaving natural gasoline.  

Liquids are brought into the plant at the slug catchers and then are taken to the stabilizer where they are heated and separated, with the gas going back into the inlet process as described above.  The liquids are introduced into a depropanizer for separation into propane and B-G mixes.  Additional liquids will be brought into the plant and stored in Y-grade tanks for storage prior to entering the stabilizer and the remainder of the process.  

A fractionator process then takes the B-G liquids

and separates the iso- and normal- butane leaving natural gasoline. The butanes are stored in presssurized vessels and the natural gasoline is stored in atmospheric tanks with a control.  

Regulated substances that are currently stored or will be stored through the time of predictive filing in this RMP include propane storage tanks, B-G mix tanks (flammable mixture), Y-grade tanks (flammable mixture), iso-butane tanks, normal-butane tanks, natural gasoline (flammable mixture), and liquids in the slug catchers inlet (flammable mixture).  An accounting of the various storage tanks, flammable mixture compositions, and determination of worst-case scenario is given following the PSM information below.

For additional detail of the various processes at the Houston Plant see the plant operations manager.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION 
The following is a summary of the accident prevention in place for the process at the facility. Because the process at the facility that are regulated by the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) risk management program (RMP) regulation are also subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA's) process safety management (PSM) standard, this summary addresses each of the OSHA PSM elements and describes the management system in place to implement accident prevention.

Process Safety Information

MarkWest Energy Partners L.P., keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes.  These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information.  The reference documents are maintained on file at the facility to provide open access.

Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in material safety data sheets (MSDSs).  This information is supplemented by docum

ents that specifically address known corrosion concerns and any known hazards associated with the inadvertent mixing of chemicals.  For the process, the facility has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters (e.g., temperature, level, composition) in key process parameter documents.  The facility ensures that the process is maintained within these limits using process controls and monitoring instruments, highly trained personnel, and protective instrument systems (e.g., automated shutdown systems).

The facility also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment.  This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, and electrical rating of equipment.  This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

MarkWest Energy Partners L.P., has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the process are identified and controlled.  Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.  

MarkWest Energy Partners L.P., will use one or more of the following techniques to identify hazards: what-if, checklist, what-if/checklist, hazard and operability (HAZOP), failure mode and effects analysis (FMEA), or fault tree analysis (FTA).  HAZOP analysis is recognized as one of the most systematic and thorough hazard evaluation techniques and will be utilized for each major process change or renovation.  The analyses are conducted using a team of people who have operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise.  This team identifies and evaluates haza

rds of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and the team makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary.

Each PHA will address the following:
a) hazards of the process,
b) previous incidents with likely potential for catastrophic consequences,
c) consequences of failure of engineering and administrative controls,
d) engineering and administrative control applicable to the hazards an their inter-relationships,
e) facility siting issues,
f) human factors.

The PHA team findings are compiled in a written report and are forwarded to local and corporate management for resolution.  Implementation of mitigation options in response to PHA findings is based on a relative risk ranking assigned by the PHA team.  This ranking helps ensure that potential accident scenarios assigned that highest risk receive immediate attention.  All approved mitigation options in response to PHA team findings are tracked until they are completed.  The final resolution of each finding is documented and retained.

To help ensure that the process controls and/or process hazards do not eventually deviate significantly from the original design safety features, the facility periodically updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results.  These periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years and will be conducted at this frequency until the process is no longer operative.  The results and findings from these updates are documented and retained.  Once again, the team findings are forwarded to management for consideration, and the final resolution of the findings is documented and retained.  

Operating Procedures

MarkWest Energy Partners L.P., maintains written procedures that address various modes of operations, such as: unit startup; normal operations; temporary operations; emergency shutdown; normal shutdown; emergency operations, and initial startup of a new process.  These procedures

can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators.  These procedures are periodically reviewed and annually certified as current and accurate.  The procedures are kept current and accurate by revising them as necessary to reflect changes made through the management of change process.  The operating procedures are centrally located and accessible to all employees.

Training

To complement the written procedures for process operations, the Houston Gas Plant has implemented a comprehensive training program for all employees involved in operating a process.  New employees receive basic training in facility operations unless they provide written certification that they have the required knowledge, skills and abilities to safely carry out their specific duties and responsibilities. All MarkWest employees at the Houston plant will be trained in PSM/RMP requirement upon hire and prior to working in PSM/RMP processes.  All operations employees will undergo refresher training at least every three years.  A training attendance record will be kept for all training activities and a verification of understanding will be conducted by a performance evaluation or through testing.

Mechanical Integrity

MarkWest Energy Partners L.P., has well-established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition.  The basic aspects of mechanical integrity include: training; written procedures; inspections and tests; correcting identified deficiencies; and applying quality assurance measures.  In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process.

Maintenance personnel receive training on an overview of the process, safety and health hazards, applicable maintenance procedures, emergency response plans, and applicable safe work practices to help e

nsure that they can perform their jobs in a safe manner.  Job plans/written procedures help ensure that work is performed in a consistent manner and provide a basis for training.  Inspections and tests are performed to help ensure that equipment functions as intended and to verify that equipment is within acceptable limits (e.g., adequate wall thickness for pressure vessels).  If a deficiency is identified, employees will correct the deficiency before placing the equipment back into service (if possible), or a management of change team will review the use of the equipment and determine what actions are necessary to ensure the safe operation of the equipment.

Another integral part of the mechanical integrity is quality assurance.  The Houston Gas Plant incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs.  This helps ensure that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made.

Management of Change

MarkWest Energy Partners L.P., has a comprehensive system to manage changes to all covered processes.  This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented.  Changes are reviewed to ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and to verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change.  Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures, are updated to incorporate these changes.  In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provided any necessary training on the change.  

Pre-startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs)

MarkWest Energy Partners L.P., conducts a PSSR for any new facility or facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information.  The PSSR confirm that constructi

on was completed in accordance with design specifications, that safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place and are adequate.  The PSSR will be reviewed and appropriately updated during the management of change process.  The PSSR will ensure that: modifications were installed as described; no other changes were made outside the original scope of work; operating procedures have been modified and communicated to operating and maintenance personnel; all necessary tests have been completed prior to start-up; all site safety, fire protection, and environmental issues have been addressed; the startup plan has been reviewed; pertinent drawing have been red-lined or updated to as-built requirements; vendor files have been updated; and training of affected personnel has been performed and documented.

Compliance Audits

To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, MarkWest Energy Partners L.P., periodically conducts an audit to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented.  Compliance audits are conducted at least every 3 years.  Both hourly and staff personnel participate as audit team members.  Team membership will include at least one person knowledgeable of the system being audited.  One member of the team must be qualified to lead the audit and be familiar with the auditing protocol being administered.  Audits will be conducted using the OSHA Verification Checklist CPL2-2.45a and the EPA Audit Guidance Checklist.  The Plant Compliance Coordinator will maintain a listing of all non-conformances identified during an audit and document closure of compliance audit action items.  The two most recent audit reports will remain on file with the documentation of closed items.

Incident Investigation

MarkWest Energy Partners L.P., promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, release, major p

roperty damage, environmental loss, or personal injury.  The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts, determine what error states led to the incident and to develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident.  The investigation team consists of the immediate supervisor, one person knowledgeable in the process, and other members with appropriate experience to investigate and analyze the incident.  The team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to facility management for resolution.  Corrective actions that are identified will be promptly addressed, resolved and tracked until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees (including contractors) whose job tasks are relevant to the investigation.  Incident investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years so that the reports can be reviewed during PHAs and PHA revalidations.

Employee Participation

MarkWest Energy Partners L.P., encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention.  Examples of employee participation range from updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information to participating as a member of a process hazard anyalsis (PHA) team.  Employees will be provided with all information created as part of the facility accident prevention program.  Specific ways that employees can be involved in the accident prevention program are documented in an employee participation plan that is maintained at the facility.

Hot Work Permit

MarkWest Energy Partners, L.P., uses a hot work permit for hot work operations including grinding, welding, and spark producing activities conducted on or near a covered process.  The hot work permit documents the fire prevention and protection requirements prior to beginning hot work operations. The

permit indicates the days on which hot work may be performed and the object upon which hot work is to be performed. Hot work permits are kept in a place that is easily accessible for the workers and on file at the office until the completion of hot work operations.

Contractors

The Houston Gas Plant uses contractors to supplement its workforce during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities.  Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, the plant has procedures in place to ensure that contractors: perform their work in a safe manner; have the appropriate knowledge and skills; are aware of the hazards in their workplace; understand what they should do in event of an emergency; understand and follow site safety rules; and inform facility personnel of any hazards that they find during their work.  This is accomplished by providing contractors with: a process overview; information about potential fire, explosion, or toxic release hazards; emergency response plan requirements; and safe work practices prior to their beginning work.  In addition, the Houston Gas Plant will only select contractors who submit certification that employees are trained in specifics and safe work practices associated with their job, and that provide safety performance documentation from the previous three years.  Finally, facility personnel periodically monitor contractor performance to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations.

CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

The processes at the Houston Gas Plant have hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation.  The following is a description of existing safety features applicable to prevention of accidental releases of regulated substances in the facility.  

Universal Prevention Activities

The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to all RMP-covered processes at the Houston Gas Plant.  Collectively, these prevention program activities prevent or mitigat

e potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors.

Specialized Safety Features

The Houston Gas Plant has safety features on many units to help (1) contain/control a release, (2) quickly detect a release, and (3) reduce the consequences of (mitigate) a release.  The following types of safety features are used in the covered process:

Release Detection

1. Hand-held hydrocarbon detectors operated by facility personnel.  Personnel are on site 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.
  
Release Containment/Control

1.  Process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate episodic releases.

2.  Valves to permit isolation of the process (manual and automated).

3.  Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high temperature)

4.  Curbing or dyking to contain liquid releases.

5.  Redundant equipment and instrumentation (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system).

Release Mitigation

1.  Deluge system for specific equipment.

2.  Trained emergency response personnel.

3.  Personal protective equipment (e.g., chemical protective clothing).

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Houston Gas Plant has had no accidents since its inception within the past 5 years.    

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION

The Houston Gas Plant maintains a written emergency response program, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment.  The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released.  The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post incident cleanup and decontamination requirements.  In addition,

the facility has procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment.  Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties.  The emergency response program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to facility processes.  The emergency response program changes are administered through the MOC process, which includes informing and/or training affected personnel in the changes. Periodic drills or tabletop exercises are conducted to test the response plan.

The overall emergency response program for the Houston Gas Plant is coordinated with the Washington County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives.  The Houston Gas Plant has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department).  This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.  In addition to periodic LEPC meetings, the Houston Gas Plant conducts periodic emergency drills that involve the LEPC and emergency response organizations, and the facility provides annual refresher training to local emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated substances in the facility.  

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Houston Gas Plant resolves all findings from PHAs, some of which result in modifications to the process.  At this time there are no findings to report.

o    Propane - 0.585
o    Butane - 0.601

-    Butane is considered to be 100% butane

-    Y-grade constituents were determined by liquids analysis as attached
-    Slug Catcher fluid constituents were determined by liquids analysis as attached
-    Natural gasoline constituents were determined by liquids analysis attached


Determination of Worst-Case and Alternative-Case Scenarios

The alternative release scenario was the slug catchers.  This was chosen because while the weight of flammable material in a slug catcher is less than other scenarios, the other tanks are nearby the propane tanks, whereas the slug catchers are on a different side of the plant and may have a different sphere of influence.
